Dear Ms. Stevens:
Attached is the Special Investigation Report for the above referenced facility. Due to the
violations identified in the report, a written corrective action plan is required. The
corrective action plan is due 15 days from the date of this letter and must include the
following:
• How compliance with each rule will be achieved.
• For any repeat violations, why the prior corrective action plan did not result
in compliance.
• Who is directly responsible for implementing the corrective action for each
violation.
• Specific time frames for each violation as to when the correction will be
completed or implemented.
• Indicate how continuing compliance will be maintained once compliance is
achieved.
• The signature of the responsible party and a date.
If you desire technical assistance in addressing these issues, please feel free to contact
me. In any event, the corrective action plan is due within 15 days. Failure to submit an
acceptable corrective action plan will result in disciplinary action.

III. INVESTIGATION
Rule Code & CPA Rule 400.12206.
Section (1) An agency shall require a staff member who has ongoing
Description contact with children or parents to be a person who has the
ability, experience, education, and training to perform the
duties assigned.
Violation Potential Rule or Statute Violation.
Type
Allegation(s) • Staff 3 assisted Youth A in running away by driving Youth
A to the bus station to meet up with the youth's boyfriend,
and then Youth A and the boyfriend left. On 12/3/2022
Staff 3 helped Youth A (age 17) pack a bag, evade the
independent living (IL) home outside cameras, and AWOL
from the home.
• Staff 3 had helped this Youth A and others to evade
cameras at the independent living home for purposes of
leaving the home.
• Staff 3 purchased cigarettes, vape pens, alcohol and
marijuana for Youth A, Youth B, and other youths.
Subsequent allegations after the initial complainant.
• Staff 3 and Youth B returned to the facility around 8:00pm
after taking Youth A to the bus stop.
• Staff 3 took Youth B to a gas station and bribed Youth B
not to tell by buying Youth B cigarettes, vape pens and a
Taco Bell dinner.
• Staff 3 has tried to contact Youth B, but it was unknown if
Staff 3 had contacted Youth A.
• On 12/4/2022 Staff 3 was terminated and escorted out of
the IL home.
Investigation Interviews:
Staff 4/Complainant
On 12/6/2022 I interviewed Staff 4 by telephone. I also spoke with
her briefly onsite on 1/4/2023. Staff 4 reported she/the agency
made this complaint and confirmed the information. Staff 4
reported that she works at the IL home one day per week on each
of the facility’s three work shifts. She worked the midnight shift on
12/3/2023.
DHHS Worker X
3

On 12/6/2022 I spoke with the Department of Health and Human
Services Worker (DHHS) X by telephone. DHHS Worker X’s role
is to assure the safety of Youth A and other youths. She is not the
assigned foster care worker responsible for the overall care of
Youth A. DHHS Worker X contacted the agency. The agency
reported not knowing about the situation of Youth A being missing
or other circumstances until around 3:00 AM the next day
(12/4/2023). Staff 4 discovered Youth A was missing as Staff 4
was preparing to leave to take Youth C to the hospital, due to a
medical issue. Staff 4 needed to take all three of the youths (who
resided in the home at the time) with her (to ensure for their
supervision) and Youth A was not in her room. It was during Staff
4’s interaction with Youth B and Youth C that both youths
eventually disclosed what had occurred pertaining to Youth A’s
absence.
Allegations: Staff assisted AWOL; staff helped the youth
avoid camaras; the staff tried to contact youths after the
incident; Youth B was bribed not to tell about AWOL with
food and vape
Staff 4
Staff 4 confirmed the information reported by DHHS Worker X as
to how she discovered Youth A’s absence from the IL home and
staff not being allowed to leave the youth home alone on her
midnight shift on 12/3/2022. Staff 4 said Youth A was not in her
room and some of Youth A’s belongings were missing. Youth B
reported to Staff 4 that she helped Youth A to AWOL.
Staff 4 reported since she could not connect with the IL program’s
on-call staff for assistance, she took Youth B and Youth C to the
hospital with her. She had Staff 5 pick Youth B up from the
hospital, as Youth B was not allowed back in the treatment area.
While at the hospital, Youth C told Staff 4 Youth B lied about
helping Youth A AWOL, and that it was Staff 3 who helped Youth
A leave the IL home. Youth C reported Staff 3 drove Youth A to
the bus station and Youth B accompanied them. Youth C
reported further that Staff 3 provided Youth B with cigarettes, a
vape pen and dinner to not tell what Staff 3 did. Staff 4 said that
Youth B later reported the same information regarding Staff 3 to
Staff 5.
Staff 4 said she also telephoned Staff 3 after the incident. Staff 3
did not answer but called her back. She asked Staff 3 if Staff 3
knew where Youth A was, and advised Staff 3, that Staff 4 and
Youth C were at the hospital. Staff 3 skipped over the question
4

about Youth A with a quick no and asked, “what’s happening at
the hospital”. Staff 3 showed up at the hospital later without notice
or a request for Staff 3 to come there.
Staff 4 said she spoke with Program Director (PD) 2 (who was on
vacation during the incident) around 5:00PM on 12/4/2023. She
informed him of the situation and what Youth C disclosed. PD 2
asked to speak with Youth C, and Youth C reported the same
information to PD 2 that Youth C had reported to her.
Staff 4 said she arrived back to the IL house when Staff 5 was
taking Youth B’s statement. She heard Youth B affirming what
Youth C reported about these allegations. Youth B then went to
Youth B’s room and came back with two Breeze vape pens, a
pack of Black and Mild’s, and another pen for marijuana that had
been left by Youth A. Youth B reported that Staff 3 would buy
them alcohol and vapes all the time. Further, that Staff 3 had also
purchased alcohol for Youth D, who was a prior youth at the
home. Youth B reported when they got their stipend funds, they
would take money from their stipend card and Staff 3 would drive
them to the marijuana dispenser. Youth B said Staff 3 would use
Staff 3’s driver’s license to buy them marijuana. Youth B reported
not knowing why Staff 3 did those things for them, because Staff 3
never asked them for monetary reimbursement.
Staff 4 said Youth A is still AWOL. Youth C was discharged last
night (12/5/22), and Youth B, was allowed to go visit Youth B’s
aunt and is not expected back to the IL home until later tonight
(12/6/2022).
Youth A
On 12/7/2022, I interviewed Youth A by telephone (due to possible
COVID issues), along with DHHS Worker XZ who was onsite with
the youth at a DHHS office.
Youth A reported living at Samaritas’ s IL home for eight months
prior to leaving to be with Person ZZ (whom she referenced as
“My husband”) up north (Hancock, Michigan) for the last couple of
days. Youth A reported that she got from the IL home to Hancock,
Michigan by bus. She said staff saw her leave because that staff
person drove her to the bus station to meet up with Person ZZ.
Youth A initially said she would not identify the staff that drove her,
that she is not “a snitch”, but then she named Staff 3 as that staff
person. She said Staff 3 took her to the Indian Track bus station
and waited with her and Person ZZ rode the bus out of town with
her. She said it was none of our business as to who purchased
5

the bus ticket for her. She said she left the IL home in the middle
of the day with Staff 3 and Youth B, who came along to the bus
station, but did not get on the bus.
Youth A said she asked Staff 3 to take her to the bus station and
that it was planned. She said she planned it for a couple of days.
She told Staff 3 her plan,asked Staff 3 the night before to help her
and Staff 3 said, “okay”. Youth A reported only the two youths in
placement knew Staff 3 would be taking her to the bus station.
Youth A affirmed that the IL home has cameras. She said the
cameras are set to view the outside, not inside of the home. She
did not specifically report Staff 3 helping her to avoid the cameras.
Youth A reported the day she left, Youth B, not Staff 3, helped her
to take her luggage/belongings to Staff 3’s car. This was with
Staff 3’s knowledge.
Youth A denied that there was a discussion about how Staff 3
would report Youth A being gone. She said Youth C stayed at the
house alone when Staff 3 drove them to the bus station. Youth A
reported after it was discovered that she was gone, Youth B and
Youth C were telephoning her, telling her, or yelling at her that she
needed to tell Children’s Services what happened. Youth A did not
disclose any information regarding Staff 3 calling her after the
departure.
Youth C
On 12/7/2022, I interviewed Youth C by telephone (due to
possible COVID issues), along with DHHS Worker X who was
onsite at the IL home.
Youth C reported on the Wednesday or Thursday prior to Youth A
AWOLing, Youth A told her Youth A was going to leave the home,
and Staff 3 was going to assist her. Youth C collaborated aspects
of what Youth A reported related to Staff 3 helping Youth A to
AWOL, driving Youth A to the bus station to meet Person ZZ,
Youth B accompanying them, them leaving her home alone, and
Staff 3 purchasing Youth A and Youth B vapes. Youth C reported
not actually seeing Staff 3 purchase the vapes but said Youth A
and Youth B told her Staff 3 had (Youth C later reported she had
witnessed such).
Youth C said Staff 3 said they were going to have to make it look
as if Youth A left the next day/on the next shift from when Youth A
actually left. This would mean that Youth A did not leave on Staff
3’s shift. Youth C said she disclosed all of what happened about
6

the incident to IL staff while she was at the hospital. Youth C said
when Staff 4 came to work for Staff 4’s shift later on Saturday,
Staff 4 asked who all were there and she told Staff 4 Youth A was
not. Staff 4 did not initially believe her. Nor did Staff 4 go upstairs
to check, even after she said she made a video showing Youth A’s
room empty. Staff 4 discovered Youth A was missing when Staff 4
had to round everyone up so Staff 4 could take Youth C to the
hospital.
Youth C reported Youth B, not Staff 3, was helping Youth A to
avoid the IL home’s cameras. Youth B had done it before to sneak
boys into the home, reportedly with Staff 3’s awareness of such.
Youth C reported knowing that later because Youth B had
commented after having a boy in the home one night, that she had
sex and Staff 3 commented “where is the condom?” Youth C said
according to Youth B the cameras only showed the driver side of
Staff 3’s car and Youth A went out the living room’s side door and
got in the passenger side of Staff 3’s car.
Staff 5
On 12/7/2022, I interviewed Staff 5 by telephone (due to possible
COVID issues), along with DHHS Worker X who was onsite at the
IL home.
Staff 5 said she was not working the day/shift that Youth A
AWOLed. She said Staff 4 called her about 2:00AM about
needing to take Youth C to the hospital, and an inability to get
Samaritas’ on-call staff. Staff 5 suggested Staff 4 round up all the
youths to take with Staff 4, and that’s when Staff 4 discovered
Youth A was missing.
Staff 5 said she and Staff 4 both reached out to Samaritas’ on-call
staff again for assistance. Around 4:00 AM Staff 4 requested Staff
5 pick Youth B up from the hospital, which Staff 5 did. Staff 5 also
spoke with Youth B about the incident, and Youth B initially said
Youth A had snuck out. Staff 5 said she made a police report
about Youth A being missing. The police came out and took the
statement and she wrote an incident report.
Staff 5 reported it was not until after she had spoken with PD 2
(around 6:00AM) to report Youth A’s AWOL and other events had
happened (Staff 3 showing up at the hospital, the IL home, and
leaving), that she learned more details of what had transpired
related to Youth A’s AWOL incident and other allegations. Staff 5
said on the morning of 12/4/2022, PD 2 had instructed her to
escort Staff 3 out the IL home and as Staff 3 was leaving the
7

home, Staff 3 reportedly tried to communicate with Youth B via a
window. Youth B told Staff 5 that. Youth B said Staff 3 knocked on
Youth B’s window. Youth B said Staff 3 asked her whether they
all had stuck to the story they came up with about Youth A
leaving. Youth B told Staff 3 that Youth C told on Staff 3. Youth B
said Staff 3 thanked her for having her back. Staff 5 reported it
was after this, that Youth B “came clean” about what had
occurred. Staff 5 confirmed the information that Staff 4 reported
Youth B had disclosed to Staff 5 about Staff 3 helping Youth A to
AWOL, taking Youth A to the bus station, trying to bribe Youth B
with Black and Mild products and other items. Also that Staff 3
moved her car, had Youth A go out the side door, so that Youth A
would not be seen putting her clothing into Staff 3’s car.
Staff 5 denied any knowledge of the youths’ plan to AWOL. She
said Youth B reported that Youth A had been planning to run away
for a week. Youth B also reported to have had a video of what
Staff 3 said to her when Staff 3 knocked on the window, but what
Staff 5 was shown was a video of Staff 3 being at the bus station
with the youths.
Youth B
On 12/8/2022, I interviewed Youth B by telephone (due to possible
COVID issues) along with DHHS Worker X who was onsite with
Youth B at the youth’s grandmother’s home.
Youth B confirmed information reported by Youth A, Youth C, Staff
4 and Staff 5 with respect to Youth A’s AWOL, how the AWOL
transpired, Staff 3’s involvement in that, Staff 3 buying her food
(McDonalds) so she would not tell, and Staff 3 knocking on her
window the next day advising her not to tell. Youth B reported
when Staff 3 knocked on her window Staff 3 told her she got fired
and for her and Youth C to stick to the story. Youth B said she told
Staff 3 she had stuck to the story, but Youth C had not.
Youth B reported the day Youth A AWOLed, she, Youth A and
Staff 3 left the home around 1:30pm. She said Youth A told her
earlier in that day that Youth A was leaving to go take a bus with
Person ZZ and that she had been planning it for about a week.
Program Director 2
On 1/4/2023, DHHS Worker XX and I interviewed Program
Director 2 (PD), onsite at the IL home.
PD 2 reported he has been serving in a dual role of program
manager and case manager since, 11/3/2022. The November
8

date is when the prior case manager, Case Manager 6 left the
agency. PD 2 reported he was on vacation at the time of the
incident. He was alerted of the incident by Staff 5 via text
message around 4:40 AM on Sunday, 12/4/2022. He reported
Staff 5 informed him Staff 4 called her informing her Staff 4
discovered Youth A was missing, that all of Youth A ‘s things were
gone, and that Youth A must have left some time around midnight
or 1:00 AM.
PD2 said he called Staff 4 and Staff 5 and each confirmed the
incident. Staff 4 reported what Youth C reported about Staff 3
helping Youth A to AWOL and the use of the cameras. Staff 4
also told him that when she arrived for her 11:00PM shift, Staff 3
told her Youth A was in her room. PD 2 reported “the protocol is
to do a check of all rooms to ensure all the girls are there,” but
Staff 4 did not. Staff 4 went with what Staff 3 reported to her.
PD 2 reported after Staff 4 and Staff 5 shared the information
about Youth A being missing, and Staff 3 helping the youth get
past the camera’s view, he reviewed the camera footage via his
phone. He said the cameras point to the front door and outside
driveway, which allows staff to see who is coming inside and
outside of the house. He reported the camera footage showed
some aspects of what Youth B reported related to them going out
the side door when Youth A was leaving the home. The three left
around 12:00 noon after Staff 3 had moved her car from full view
of the cameras. He said Staff 3 and Youth B arrived back to the
house around 3:26PM and camera footage showed Staff 3 park
her car in full view of the camera. Youth B got out the car and
waved at the camera. Later at around 8:00pm, Staff 3 is seen
taking Youth B out, reportedly to the store. PD 2 showed us some
of that footage via his phone.
PD 2 reported on 12/4/2022, prior to 7:00AM, he called Staff 3 and
spoke with her about Youth A not being at the IL home. Staff 3
told him Youth A was at the house when she left the house the
prior night at 11:00PM. PD 2 reported during their investigation of
this incident, they interviewed Staff 3 and Staff 3 reported the last
time she saw Youth A that evening was at 8:00PM. Given that
statement from Staff 3, PD 2 said they asked Staff 3 whether she
left a youth alone that night and Staff 3 did not answer. PD2 said
he also contacted Person ZZ (via Person ZZ’s mother) and
confirmed that Youth A was with Person ZZ. He also spoke briefly
with Youth A but did not go into the allegations. He said the
agency purchased a bus ticket for Youth A to return to the IL
home, but Youth A did not return. On 12/7/2022, Youth A reported
9

DHHS did not want her to return. Chief Administrator 1 confirmed
that information with DHHS and Youth A will not be returning to
the IL home.
Staff 3
On 1/4/2023, DHHS Worker XX and I interviewed Staff 3 at Staff
3’s home. DHHS Worker XX read the allegations to Staff 3.
Staff 3 denied the allegations. She affirmed her termination. She
said she had been employed with the agency for a year and a
half. She verified that the agency had spoken with her about the
incident and her termination. She said Chief Administrator 1 told
her that since this was the second time they had spoken with her
about allegations, they had to let her go.
Staff 3 acknowledged knowing Youth A, Youth B, Youth C and
Youth D. She said Youth D moved from the IL home a while ago.
She stated it was not true about “me sneaking the girls out and me
moving my car”. She said her car was leaking power steering fluid,
and her husband told her to move it so she could see if it was
leaking. She denied driving Youth A to the bus station. She said
she always works a double shift on Saturday (7:00AM-3:00PM &
3:00PM-11:00PM) and Saturday was the last time she saw Youth
A. She said Youth A was in the IL house when she left.
Staff 3 reported when Staff 4 came in for the 11:00PM shift
change, Staff 3 assumed Youth A was in her room. Staff 3
reported she never heard Youth A leave and she was not sure
what time Youth A would have left. She said Youth A rarely came
out of her room. She further stated Youth A came out maybe to
get food and Youth A’s room was always trashy.
Staff 3 denied going to the bus station with the youths on that
Saturday or Sunday. She did not know why the other youths
would say she had. She reported only knowing that Youth A had
checked on the price of a bus ticket months ago. She said Youth
A was always talking with her, Staff 4, and Staff 5 about running
away, but Youth A never ran. We asked Staff 3 whether she told
PD 2 about Youth A talking about running away. Staff 3
responded, “Yes. He just thought she was B.S.ing”.
Staff 3 reported Youth A’s AWOL was brought to her attention on
Sunday (12/4/2022) by Staff 4. Staff 4 called her to say Youth C
was at the hospital so she went to the hospital to relieve Staff 4.
Contrary to what Staff 4 reported, Staff 3 said Staff 4 told her to
come to the hospital to relieve her. At that time Staff 4 told her
10

Youth A was missing. Staff 3 said if Youth A left on her shift,
Youth A must have left when Staff 3 was at the store with Youth B
and Youth C. Staff 3 reported they went to the store because
Youth B wanted something to drink. They left Youth A at the
home.
We asked Staff 3 whether she checked to verify that Youth A was
in her room when she returned from the store. Staff 3 responded,
“No”. Staff 3 reported being gone for only 10-15 minutes and that
she had done this before. Staff 3 acknowledged the agency has
protocol around when staff can and cannot leave youths home
alone. She reported staff being able to leave a youth home alone
during the day, 7:00AM-3:00PM. They cannot do so during the
evenings, 3:00PM- 7:00 AM. During the latter hours the staff must
be with the youths. Staff 3 said she went to the store twice. She
went at 11:00AM and later “when it was dark,” but she did not
recall that being at 8:00PM. She said it was “more like 6:00PM or
7:00PM”. She again reported not knowing when Youth A left the
IL home.
None of the youths or other staff interviewed reported an
awareness of Staff 3 assisting other youths to AWOL.
Cigarettes/Marijuana/vape allegation:
Staff 4
On 12/6/2022, I interviewed Staff 4 by telephone and spoke with
her briefly onsite on 1/4/2023. Staff 4 reported she/the agency
made this complaint.
She said she heard Youth B affirming what Youth C reported
about these allegations. Youth B then went to Youth B’s room
and came back with two Breeze vape pens, a pack of Black and
Mild’s, and another pen for marijuana that had been left my Youth
A. Youth B reported that Staff 3 would buy them alcohol and
vapes all the time. Further, that Staff 3 had also purchased alcohol
for Youth D, who was a prior youth at the home. Youth B reported
when they got their stipend funds, they would take money from
their stipend card and Staff 3 would drive them to the marijuana
dispenser. Youth B said Staff 3 would use Staff 3’s driver’s
license to buy them marijuana. Youth B reported not knowing why
Staff 3 did those things for them, because Staff 3 never charged
them.
Youth A
On 12/7/2022, via methods as described earlier, DHHS Worker
XZ and I interviewed Youth A. Youth A reported disapproval of
11

the IL home because she felt it was more like a residential
program, and that youths were doing the “wrong things”, like
sneaking boys in the home and smoking marijuana. The latter of
which Youth A reported PD 2 told them if they are going to do it, to
do it outside. We asked Youth A whether she was part of “doing
the wrong things” related to substances, and she reported she
was not. We apprised Youth A that there were reports that Staff 3
had given youths in the home cigarettes and marijuana. We asked
her about that. Youth A stated, “I used a vape, I won’t lie.” She
said Staff 3 gave her the vape, which was in September 2022.
She reported Staff 3 provided marijuana, alcohol and vapes to
Youth B. She said Staff 3 did not bring in the items. They paid for
the items with money from their stipends. Staff 3 purchased the
items while they were with Staff 3. Youth A reported, Staff 3 also
purchased items for Youth B and Youth D. Staff 3 purchased
vapes for Youth B more than 10 times, alcohol for Youth B once,
and weed, which Staff 3 would get from the dispenser, an
unknown number of times. Youth A said she asked Staff 3 to get
her a vape pen on her birthday and Youth B and Youth D had also
asked Staff 3 for things, which they all paid for upfront.
Youth A reported not knowing why Staff 3 made the purchases
knowing that doing so would get her in trouble. Youth A denied
any other staff purchasing vapes, cigarettes, marijuana and or
alcohol for her or any youths.
Youth C
On 12/7/2022, via methods as described earlier, DHHS Worker X
and I interviewed Youth C. Youth C reported after Staff 3 and
Youth B returned from dropping Youth A off at the bus station, that
sometime around 8:00PM Staff 3 took her and Youth B to the
store. Staff 3 asked her whether she wanted Staff 3 to buy her
Black and Mild cigarettes. Youth C reported she declined and
Staff 3 bought Black and Mild’s and a vape item for Youth B using
Youth B’s money. Youth C did not know if Youth B asked Staff 3
to purchase those items or whether Staff 3 volunteered.
DHHS Worker X asked Youth C about youths smoking weed at
the IL home, and whether PD2 reported it was okay for them to
smoke weed as long as they did not do so in the home. Youth C
reported staff would smell marijuana in the youths rooms and
reported to PD2. PD 2 never witnessed it. PD 2 had a meeting
with all of the youths about weed and smoking. PD2 told them “I
can’t stop you from doing it, but you can’t do it here”.
Staff 5:
12

On 12/7/2022, via methods as described earlier, DHHS Worker X
and I interviewed Staff 5. Staff 5 confirmed the allegations made
by Youth B about the incident. Youth B went into her room and
came back with three cigarette vapes which Youth B reported
Staff 3 bought for her. Youth B also brought/showed a marijuana
pen, which Youth B said belonged to Youth A. Youth B reported
that Youth A said Staff 3 bought the marijuana pen for Youth A.
Staff 5 did not say why Youth B reported having the marijuana pen
that reportedly belonged to Youth A. Additionally, that according
to Youth B, Staff 3 started buying Youth B vape pens, cigarette
items, as well as others these items, within two weeks of Youth
B’s 7/15/2022 placement at the IL home.
Staff 5 denied any direct knowledge of Staff 3 buying cigarettes,
vapes, other substances for the youths. She acknowledged that
the staff had experienced incidents of the youths using
substances. She said, there had been a lot of issues with the
youths smoking marijuana. She reported knowing that because
they had smelled it. She said all the staff had been trying to
understand how to handle it. They have knocked on the specific
youth’s door and reminded the youth that is not allowed. They
have also addressed it with PD2 who has also spoken with the
youths. Staff 5 reported they have been advised that if the matter
is a safety concern, they are allowed to enter the youth’s room,
but it’s not clear whether they can confiscate the item. Staff 5
reported the youths said PD2 told them, about two weeks ago, PD

Youth B
On 12/8/2022, via methods as described earlier, DHHS Worker X
and I interviewed Youth B. Youth B also confirmed Staff 3

Youth B reported some youths would drink in front of Staff 3, and
Staff 3 had allowed she and other youths to vape. Youth B said
Staff 3 “didn’t care” that they did this, but Staff 3 did not smoke or
drink.
13

Youth B admitted youths are not supposed to smoke or drink in

policy that the IL home has. She also affirmed Youth C’s and Staff

substances and advising against such use at the IL home.
DHHS Worker XX
On 12/9/2022 I spoke with DHHS Worker XX. She reported she
was advised by Chief Administrator 1 that Staff 3 was terminated
on 12/16/2022 and they were getting the police involved with
possible prosecution. Also, it was noted that P2 reported going to

Program Director 2 & Staff 3
On 1/4/2023, DHHS Worker XX and I interviewed Program
Director 2, onsite at the IL home.
PD 2 denied any knowledge of Staff 3 purchasing substances for
youths. He only knew the information that was reported by Youth

telling any youth it’s ok to use these items. He has told all the

Staff 3
On 1/4/2023, DHHS Worker XX and I interviewed Staff 3 at Staff
3’s home. DHHS Worker XX read the allegations to Staff 3. Staff
3 denied the allegations. She said it is not true that she bought
the youths vapes, cigarettes, marijuana, alcohol or Taco Bell. She

That I didn’t buy the things for the kids to bribe them”. She said
she was also never told that she could not buy things for the
youths.
Staff 3 said, Youth B goes home for the weekends, and that is
where Youth B gets her Black and Mild’s, marijuana, and vape
14

pens. Staff 3 did not report how she knew that that is where or
when Youth B gets these items. She reported it was Samaritas’

items in Youth B’s room. Case Manager 6 asked Staff 3 to retrieve

Staff 3 reported, in regard to there being a video of her buying
Black and Mild cigarettes, she purchased them for her husband.
Her husband wanted them and he wanted a vape as he has them
at home. Staff 3 said Youth B snatched the Black and Milds from
her. She tried to get them back, asked for them back. She said
this happened at a Sunoco gas station.
It is worth noting that Staff 3 reported having a cognitive learning
disability. She denied any substance use or abuse.

MISACWIS Case records which showed:

12/3/2022. She is a permanent court ward.
• Youth B is a temporary court ward who was placed at the

• Youth C is a permanent court ward. She was placed at the

facility from 1/22/2022 to 9/26/2022.
Incident report dated 12/4/2022 completed by Staff 5 that

• Information as indicated in the complaint based on
reporting by Youth B related to Staff 3 assisting Youth A to
leave the home between 12:00PM and 1:00PM on
Saturday.
Employment information for Staff 3 showing:
• She was hired by the agency 3/26/2021.
• She was terminated from her position 12/17/2022.
Video footage from DHHS X, which showed:
• The bedroom Youth A had occupied which showed:
➢ A trashy setting, with empty water bottles, partially

➢ A bed without sheets on the bed, and pillows
without pillow cases, and what appeared to be a
15

comforter balled up on the bed and other items, like

• Four other videos, which showed:
➢ Youth A outside, in a parking lot walking toward the
Indiana trails bus station. She is smiling saying

someone video tapes her. Thereon, the footage

Staff 3 is walking ahead of Youth A only the back of
Staff 3 is seen at this time.
➢ Youth A playing around, by hiding behind a brick

➢ Youth A walking inside the building, Staff 3 is seen

➢ Youth A and Staff 3 sitting in chairs in what appears

Youth Bs statement written by Staff 5 which indicated:

Video footage from PD 2’s cell phone which showed:

Youth D’s interview from DHHS Worker XX completed on
1/6/2023 outside Taco Bell that indicated Youth D:
16

• Reported living at the IL house from 1/3/2022 to sometime

• Stated Staff 3 has a disability and so a lot of the girls would

Staff 3 offering.
• Stated everyone took advantage of Staff 3. That the girls,
mostly referring to Youth B convinced Staff 3 to do it. She
stated Youth B lies a lot and causes a lot of drama.
• Stated Youth A always talked about wanting to AWOL and

including PD 2. Youth A never actually left so no one

Analysis Based on evidence revealed through interviews the agency is not
in compliance with the rule. Staff 3’s action of assisting a youth to
leave her IL placement without authorization, and aiding youths in
substance purchasing demonstrated Staff 3 did not show the

assigned.
Conclusion VIOLATION ESTABLISHED
Rule Code & CPA Rule 400.12503.

Violation Additional Finding
Type
Allegation The agency’s lack of supervision and protocol follow through
contributed to a youth being able to leave the facility without
authorization.
Investigation Interviews:
17

Youth C
Youth C reported on the Thursday or Friday before Youth A’s
AWOL, she told PD 2 a staff person was about to help Youth A
AWOL. Youth C said the staff thinks she’s a joke and so, PD 2
replied to her telling her this information was “okay, have fun”.
Youth C said she had reported to PD 2 that the staff who was
working at the time that she was talking with PD 2 was the staff
who was going to help Youth A. She said Staff 3 was the staff
working at that time, but she did not specifically say to PD 2 that it
was Staff 3 who was going to help the youth leave.
Youth A, Youth B, and Youth C
All of these youths reported that Youth C was left at the IL house
alone while Staff 3, Youth A, and Youth B went to the bus station.
PD 2
PD 2 reported certain protocols were not followed by staff. He
reported Staff 4 told him when she arrived for her 11:00PM shift
(on the night/day of the incident) Staff 3 told her Youth A was in
her room. PD 2 reported “the protocol is to do a check of all
rooms to ensure all the girls are there” but Staff 4 did not. Staff 4
went with what Staff 3 reported to her.
PD 2 reported the protocol for when a staff is leaving the home to
take a youth somewhere is to text him to say they are leaving the
house. He reported Staff 3 has followed protocol in the past to
advise that Staff 3 was taking a youth to an appointment, etc., but
Staff 3 did not text him about taking Youth B to the store that
evening. PD 2 did not know why Staff 3, or others, did not follow
protocol.
PD 2 was asked whether he was told by a youth that Youth A was
planning to AWOL. PD 2 acknowledged that on Friday (12/2/2022)
Youth C told him Youth A was going to AWOL and a staff was
going to help Youth A. PD 2 said, Youth C would not disclose
when or how the incident was to occur, or what staff. PD 2
admitted he did not talk with Youth A or the staff about what Youth
C alleged. Also, he did not mention this matter to Chief
Administrator 1 whom he reported was to be in charge during his
vacation leave from 12/2/2022-12/15/2022. PD 2 reported he did
not take Youth C seriously because Youth A had never AWOLed
before. Youth A basically stayed in her room.
PD 2 affirmed Staff 3’s termination from the agency.
Staff 3
18

Staff reported youths are not to be left in the home alone between
3:00PM- 7:00AM. She reported that she left Youth A alone when
she took Youth B and Youth C to the store, which was more like
6:00PM or 7:00PM. She acknowledged there was a protocol
whereby the staff were to text PD2 that they were taking a youth
away from the facility, but then she reported they don’t have to
text PD 2 to say they are taking the youths to the store or a
medical appointment or elsewhere. She reported “that was a long
time ago.” She did not text PD 2 or Chief Administrator 1 that she
was taking Youth B and Youth C away from the IL home.
Analysis There were three instances in which the agency failed to follow its
own policies/procedures/ protocols.
• The agency policy is that youths are not to be left alone
during the hours of 3:00PM-7:00AM. Youth A, Youth B, and
Youth C reported that Youth C was left alone in the house
while Staff 3 transported Youth A to the bus station.
• The identified protocol is for staff to do a check of all rooms
at the start of a shift to verify that all youths are accounted
for. Staff 4 did not check rooms when she came on duty.
She took Staff 3’s word that all youth were in their rooms.
• The agency policy is for staff to contact PD2 or the Chief
Administrator when staff take youth away from the house.
Staff 3 failed to contact PD2 or the Chief Administrator
when she took Youth B to the store.
In all these instances, the agency did not adhere to its
policy/procedures related to supervising youths and reporting that
a youth is being taken away from the IL home.
Consultation:
To better assess and or plan around safety, and supervisory
issues and risks, it is advised that the PD2 be very mindful of what
a youth reports to him, particularly around truancy issues.
Conclusion VIOLATION ESTABLISHED
REPEAT VIOLATION ESTABLISHED

sir_summary.summary: A staff member (Staff 3) at a Samaritas independent living home in Flint assisted a 17-year-old youth (Youth A) to run away by driving her to a bus station, helped her evade surveillance cameras, and later attempted to bribe another youth to keep quiet. The investigation also substantiated that Staff 3 repeatedly purchased cigarettes, vape pens, alcohol, and marijuana for multiple youths in the home. The agency itself was found non-compliant for failing to follow its own supervision policies, including staff not conducting required room checks and not reporting when youths were taken off-site. The evidence clearly shows Staff 3 was primarily culpable for the direct harm and violations, while agency management shares blame for inadequate oversight and procedural failures.

sir_violation_level.justification: The report substantiates multiple severe violations aligning with 'Safety and Violence' and 'Environmental or supervision failures' criteria. Staff 3 actively assisted a youth in running away (AWOL) by transporting her to a bus station, which constitutes a serious safety risk and a supervision failure. Furthermore, Staff 3 purchased cigarettes, vape pens, alcohol, and marijuana for multiple youths, directly contributing to substance use and creating unsafe conditions. The agency also failed to follow its own supervision protocols, leaving a youth alone during prohibited hours. These are not minor policy lapses; they are actions that directly endangered youth safety and well-being.
